conclusion: The current balance has a coil with n turns in a uniform magnetic field B, with horizontal side length L.
When a current I flows through the coil, the magnetic force causes a deflection balanced by adjusting weights.
The magnetic force F on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is given by F = n I L B sin(theta).
Given the current is perpendicular to the field, sin(theta) = 1.
Initially, with current I in one direction, the force is balanced by the weights.
When the current is reversed, the direction of the force is also reversed.
To balance the reversed force, an additional mass m is added to the left pan.
The force due to the additional mass m in gravitational field g is mg.
The magnetic force after reversing the current must equal this additional force: n I L B = mg.
Rearrange the equation to solve for B: B = mg / (n I L).
The magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B is B = mg / (n I L).
